greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least number k >= 0 such that (n!+k)/(n+k) is an integer.
comment: For n > 2, in order for (n!+k)/(n+k) to be an integer, the smallest integer possible is 2. Thus, a(n) <= n!-2n for all n > 2.
Let q = (n!+k)/(n+k). Then, k = (n!-n)/(q-1)-n. So, a(n) = d-n, where d is the smallest divisor (> n) of n!-n. (for all n >= 4) - _Hiroaki Yamanouchi_, Sep 29 2014
link: Hiroaki Yamanouchi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..79
results.author: _Derek Orr_, May 17 2014
ext: a(13), a(15), a(21), a(25), a(31) and a(33) from _Hiroaki Yamanouchi_, Sep 29 2014
